abstract.p: Dr Paul R Epstein letter on Sept 1 article cites role of intense drought in forest fires in calling for accelerated clean energy program to restabilize climate

block.p: The Congressional Research Service's report on forest fires (news article, Sept. 1) admirably addresses management practices that increase vulnerability to fire. It is curious, however, that this exposure receives minimal attention. Intense drought fueled the flames this year, just as it did in previous American fires in the 1930's and again in 1988 -- the year that shook our sense of immunity to global warming's impacts.

The Congressional Research Service's report on forest fires (news article, Sept. 1) admirably addresses management practices that increase vulnerability to fire. It is curious, however, that this exposure receives minimal attention. Intense drought fueled the flames this year, just as it did in previous American fires in the 1930's and again in 1988 -- the year that shook our sense of immunity to global warming's impacts.

The summer of 2000 will be remembered as a reminder of the need to protect habitat, wildlife and health. But the human tendency to underestimate rates of change and the potential for abrupt losses is costing us dearly. Forest fire prevention must also include an accelerated clean energy program in order to restabilize the climate system.
PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D. Boston, Sept. 1, 2000
The writer is associate director, Harvard Medical School Center for Health and Global Environment.
